intro: Cassia fuscescens, commonly known as the black cassia, is a shrub native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa and Asia. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod-bearing fruits. The plant produces yellow flowers followed by elongated, dark brown pods that contain flat, kidney-shaped seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in disturbed areas or along roadsides. The leaves and pods are used in traditional medicine and as a source of dye.
